dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, it's like we're all living inside this massive, incredibly complex machine that we built but nobody has the manual for.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, it's like we're all living inside this massive, incredibly complex machine that we built but nobody has the manual for.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Dan Davies' book, The Unaccountability Machine, really nails that feeling. He talks about these 'accountability sinks'—where things go wrong, but there's no one person to blame. It's just... the system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Dan Davies' book, The Unaccountability Machine, really nails that feeling. He talks about these 'accountability sinks'-where things go wrong, but there's no one person to blame. It's just... the system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The first is his observation that our world is rife with accountability sinks: places where things are clearly going wrong, but where there is no one to blame. Instead, the entire system is at fault, and the system has no way of seeing or correcting the problem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he points out that every system, uh, has to do more than just its main job. It has to keep itself going, coordinate people, plan ahead... even an Elton John cover band has roles for all that!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he points out that every system, uh, has to do more than just its main job. It has to keep itself going, coordinate people, plan ahead... even an Elton John cover band has roles for all that!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Second, Davies points out that every social system needs not only to pursue its mission but also to preserve itself. These include providing sufficient resources to the people doing the work; coordinating things in the here and now; looking ahead from the here and now to the there and then; and maintaining the human participants focus on what the organization is for (its guiding philosophy).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Like, you've got the musicians, the conductor, the tour manager... it's a whole ecosystem just to mimic one guy's concerts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Like, you've got the musicians, the conductor, the tour manager... it's a whole ecosystem just to mimic one guy's concerts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Davies gives the example of an Elton John cover band, where these tasks are carried out, roughly, by [the] musicians, conductor, tour manager, artistic director, and Elton John.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And delegation is key, right? You can't micromanage everything. You set a thermostat instead of watching the squirrel cage temperature every minute.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And delegation is key, right? You can't micromanage everything. You set a thermostat instead of watching the squirrel cage temperature every minute.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Third, delegation is crucial to reducing complexities and keeping an organizations mission manageable. You do not need to watch the temperature inside the squirrel cage minute by minute; you just need to set a thermostat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then the feedback loops have to be strong. If the system can't amplify the right external signals or process them in time, things just... fall apart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then the feedback loops have to be strong. If the system can't amplify the right external signals or process them in time, things just... fall apart.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fourth, it is important to build strong feedback loops. This means amplifying the outside signals that you most need to see, and maintaining enough internal processing power to act on them before it is too late.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's where management cybernetics comes in. Stafford Beer, this counterculture management guru, thought a lot about balancing information flow in bureaucracies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's where management cybernetics comes in. Stafford Beer, this counterculture management guru, thought a lot about balancing information flow in bureaucracies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The guru who made the most progress in building management cybernetics was the counterculture-era management consultant Stafford Beer, whose book Brain of the Firm explored how bureaucracies can be reformed so that the internal flow of information between deciders and decided-upon is kept in balance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Felix Martin in the FT called Davies' approach like 'psychoanalysis for non-human intelligences.' Which is such a cool way to put it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Felix Martin in the F T called Davies' approach like 'psychoanalysis for non-human intelligences.' Which is such a cool way to put it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Reviewing The Unaccountability Machine in the Financial Times, Felix Martin describes Davies approach as a kind of psychoanalysis for non-human intelligences, with Stafford Beer as Sigmund Freud.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Because these systems aren't people, but they have a kind of logic—or illogic—of their own. And we're stuck inside them, getting richer but maybe more miserable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because these systems aren't people, but they have a kind of logic-or illogic-of their own. And we're stuck inside them, getting richer but maybe more miserable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are left with a globe-spanning network of profoundly alien leviathans that boss us around and make us unhappy, even as they make us fabulously rich compared to previous generations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild to think we're 15 times wealthier than pre-industrial societies, yet so unhappy. Maybe because we evolved for tribes of 150, not global networks of billions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild to think we're fifteen times wealthier than pre-industrial societies, yet so unhappy. Maybe because we evolved for tribes of one hundred fifty, not global networks of billions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: How can we be at least 15 times richer than our pre-industrial Agrarian Age predecessors, and yet so unhappy? One explanation is that we are not wired for it: nothing in our heritage or evolutionary past prepared us to deal with a society of more than 150 people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And now we're bossed around by these leviathans we created but don't really get. Davies doesn't give all the answers, but he frames the problem perfectly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now we're bossed around by these leviathans we created but don't really get. Davies doesn't give all the answers, but he frames the problem perfectly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unfortunately, Davies does not give us much of an answer. Nonetheless, he deserves credit for defining the task we face and pointing us toward a new intellectual path forward.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. At least he's pointing us toward a new way to think about steering this giant, messy boat we're all on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. At least he's pointing us toward a new way to think about steering this giant, messy boat we're all on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pioneered by the computer scientist Norbert Wiener and the political scientist Herbert Simon, the approach was named for the Greek word kyberntikos: good at steering a boat.
